importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the announcement of the expulsion of two top generals, marking a significant development in China's anti-corruption campaign and timing just before the Central Committee's Fourth Plenum.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The anti-corruption drive in the People’s Liberation Army began in 2023, setting the context for the current purges and signaling a long-term trend in military and political discipline.
The current expulsions in October 2025 are part of an ongoing and intensified campaign, with key decisions expected at the upcoming Central Committee Plenum.

keyTakeAways: Two top Chinese military leaders, He Weidong and Miao Hua, have been expelled from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army over corruption charges.
He Weidong, the second-highest-ranking general, was also a vice-chairman of the Central Military Commission and a member of the Politburo, making this one of the most powerful purges in decades.

Miao Hua, previously removed from the Central Military Commission in June, is now formally expelled, and both officers are accused of serious violations of party discipline and duty-related crimes involving large sums of money.
The expulsions are part of a broader anti-corruption campaign initiated in 2023, with a focus on senior military officials who have been absent from public view for months.
These actions are seen as part of President Xi Jinping’s broader 'cleaning house' initiative to consolidate power and ensure political discipline within the military and party leadership.

The removal of He Weidong, who previously commanded the Eastern Theatre Command in Fujian province — a key region near Taiwan — suggests strategic and operational implications in cross-strait relations.
The Pentagon noted He’s role in planning aggressive live-fire drills around Taiwan after U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit in August 2022, highlighting international security concerns.
The expulsions are expected to be formalized at the upcoming Central Committee’s Fourth Plenum, where new appointments to the Central Military Commission will be made.
This purge marks the first removal of a sitting general from the Central Military Commission since the 1966–1976 Cultural Revolution, indicating a significant shift in military leadership dynamics.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Miao was previously under investigation and removed from the Central Military Commission, and his formal expulsion underscores the scope and severity of the anti-corruption campaign.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, China expelled two top military officials, He Weidong and Miao Hua, from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army over corruption charges, marking the first removal of a sitting general from the Central Military Commission since the 1966–1976 Cultural Revolution. He Weidong, a close associate of President Xi Jinping and a member of the Politburo, was also the second-highest-ranking general and previously commanded the Eastern Theatre Command in Fujian province, a region critical to Taiwan-related military planning. Miao Hua, the former top political officer, had been under investigation since 2023. The expulsions are part of a broader anti-corruption campaign launched in 2023, with many officials reportedly missing from public view. Analysts interpret these actions as part of President Xi’s ongoing effort to consolidate power and ensure loyalty within the military and party leadership. The decisions are expected to be formalized at the upcoming Central Committee’s Fourth Plenum, signaling a significant shift in China’s military and political leadership.
title: China expels two top generals from Communist Party in anti-corruption crackdown
